metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Eosinophil Responses During COVID-19 Infections and Coronavirus Vaccination Eosinophil Responses During COVID-19 Infections and Coronavirus Vaccination 1 2

body_text.text: effects in a number of diseases. Recently, eosinophils have been shown to have a variety of other 48 functions, including immunoregulation and antiviral activity. Eosinophil levels vary dramatically 49 in a number of clinical settings, especially following eosinophil-targeted therapy, which is now 50 available to selectively deplete these cells. There are key COVID-19-related questions 51 concerning eosinophils whose answers affect recommended prevention and care. First, do 52 patients with eosinophilia-associated diseases have an altered course of COVID-19? Second, do 53 patients with eosinopenia (now intentionally induced by biological drugs) have unique COVID-54 19 susceptibility and/or disease course? This is a particularly relevant question as eosinopenia is 55 associated with acute respiratory deterioration during infection with the Severe Acute 56

Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-Corona Virus (CoV)-2, the causative agent of 57 do eosinophils contribute to the lung pathology induced during COVID-19 and will they 58 contribute to immunopotentiation potentially associated with emerging COVID-19 vaccines? 59
Herein, we address these timely questions and project considerations during the emerging 60 COVID-19 pandemic. 61 62

Eosinophils normally account for only a small percentage of circulating leukocytes (1-3%), but 64 their levels can vary in a variety of disease states. 1-3 Their level is clinically relevant as 65 eosinophils are potent pro-inflammatory cells, primarily due to their pre-formed granules, which 66 are packed with cytotoxic proteins, including major basic protein (one of the most basically 67 charged molecules in the body), eosinophil peroxidase, and two RNAses (eosinophil cationic 68 protein and eosinophil neurotoxin). In addition to their pro-inflammatory effects, evidence is 69 emerging, albeit primarily in mice, that eosinophils have pleotropic roles as regulatory cells There are a number of diseases associated with eosinophil expansion in which eosinophils are 78 causally related to the disease pathology, such as subsets of moderate and severe asthma. 79

Accordingly, a number of clinically approved biological antibody-based precision therapies are 80 now available that directly target eosinophils, resulting in eosinophil depletion. 5 These drugs 81 include those that neutralize the eosinophil growth and activating factor interleukin 5 (IL-5) (e.g., 82 mepolizumab and reslizumab) and drugs that directly induce eosinophil depletion by antibody-83 dependent cellular cytotoxicity (e.g., the anti-IL-5 receptor drug benralizumab). 6 These drugs 84 have remarkable beneficial effects in a growing number of diseases, including asthma, 85 hypereosinophilic syndrome, and eosinophilic granulomatous polyangiitis (formerly known as 86 Churg Strauss syndrome), and additional clinical indications are actively being pursued. As a 87 result, there is now an increasing number of patients with biological drug-induced eosinopenia. 7 88

Though patients with abnormally low eosinophil levels (referred to as eosinopenia) might be 89 considered at risk for diseases normally controlled by eosinophils, there have been no major side 90 effects associated with these therapies to date. In addition to biological drug-induced 91 eosinopenia, eosinophil depletion occurs in response to multiple triggers of acute inflammation, 8 92 including during sepsis, and multiple studies have consistently shown that low eosinophil levels 93 correlate with poor outcome in critically ill patients. 9 94

There are now key COVID-19-related questions concerning eosinophils whose answers affect 96 recommended prevention and care. First, do patients with eosinophilia-associated diseases have 97 an altered course of COVID-19? Second, do patients with eosinopenia have unique COVID-19 98 disease features? This is a particularly relevant question as eosinopenia has already been reported 99 in patients with acute respiratory deterioration during infection with the Severe Acute 100
Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-Corona Virus (CoV)-2, the causative agents of COVID-19. 10 101

Third, do eosinophils contribute to the lung pathology induced during COVID-19 and will they 102 contribute to adverse events associated with emerging COVID-19 vaccines? Indeed, eosinophil-103 associated lung pathology is known to occur following certain viral infections (e.g., respiratory 104 syncytial virus [RSV] ) and importantly is a known complication in prior SARS-CoV-1 105 vaccination studies (see Table 1 ). On the basis of prior experience with SARS-CoV vaccines, it 106 is expected that COVID-19 vaccines will need careful safety evaluations for immunopotentiation 107 that might increase infectivity and/or eosinophilic infiltration. 11 108 109 110

The role of eosinophils in mucosal immune responses in the respiratory tract has largely focused 112 on the detrimental impact that these cells can have in inflammatory responses due to their potent 113 pro-inflammatory function. On the other hand, preclinical studies (mainly in mice) have shown 114 that eosinophils are equipped with an assortment of molecular tools that enable them to 115 recognize, respond, and orchestrate antiviral responses to respiratory viruses. 12 Human 116 eosinophils express several endosomal toll-like receptors (TLRs), including TLR3, TLR7 and 117 TLR9, that detect viral microbe-associated molecular patterns. 13-15 TLR7 enables eosinophils to 118 recognize single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) viruses like coronavirus, and stimulating this receptor 119 in human eosinophils triggers eosinophil cytokine production, degranulation, superoxide and 120 nitric oxide (NO) generation, and prolonged cellular survival. 14-16 Eosinophil-derived neurotoxin 121 (EDN/RNAse2) and eosinophil cationic protein (ECP/RNAse3) from human eosinophils reduce 122 infectivity of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) by a ribonuclease-dependent mechanism. 17, 18 123
body_text.section: EOSINOPHIL RESPONSES DURING RESPIRATORY VIRUS INFECTIONS 111

body_text.text: Both human and murine eosinophils produce NO via inducible NO synthase that can have direct 124 antiviral effects on parainfluenza virus (PIV) and RSV. 16, 19, 20 Eosinophils are able to produce Although these data substantiate the antiviral potential of eosinophils, the clinical significance of 146 eosinophils in antiviral responses in human disease continues to remain debatable. Patients with 147 eosinophilic asthma have an increased risk for viral-induced asthma exacerbations, and there is 148 mounting evidence that patients with eosinophilic asthma may actually have reduced innate 149 responses against respiratory viruses. 28-30 Importantly, biologic agents that decrease pulmonary 150 eosinophil levels reduce asthma exacerbations, and patients with asthma treated with these 151 agents have not been reported to have increased viral infections. 29, 31-36 Rosenberg et al. 152 suggested that eosinophils in the respiratory tract might represent a "double-edged sword", 153 promoting antiviral responses against some respiratory viruses that could become dysregulated 154 during allergic disease given their increased numbers and/or activation status, ultimately 155 resulting in an exaggerated host response that can lead to host tissue damage. 37 The growing 156 number of biologic agents that target eosinophils may be useful tools to help clarify the role 157 Conversely, multiple studies have identified older age, male sex, hypertension, coronary heart 193 disease, and diabetes as being consistent risk factors for severe COVID-19 disease. 10, 43, 47-49 194 The mechanisms for the male predominance of COVID-19 severity are not known, but it is 195 notable that allergic lung responses to RSV have increased severity in male mice by a TSLP-196 dependent mechanism, and eosinophil associated diseases such as eosinophilic esophagitis and 197 In the decade following these early observations, a series of mouse studies (see Table 1
body_text.section: EOSINOPHIL RESPONSES DURING RESPIRATORY VIRUS INFECTIONS 111

body_text.text: There are emerging eosinophil-related considerations concerning COVID-19 (Table 2 ). Although 261 current data are limited, there is little supportive evidence that patients with eosinophil-262 associated diseases will have an altered course of COVID-19, provided that they are not 263 immunosuppressed from concurrent medications or by their primary disease process. Likewise, 264 though preclinical studies have provided compelling experimental evidence that eosinophils have 265 potential antiviral activity, there is no evidence that patients with eosinopenia induced by the 266 recently approved anti-eosinophil therapeutics have increased susceptibility to viruses. Whether 267 the acquired eosinopenia associated with COVID-19 is directly contributing to the disease course 268

has not yet been determined, but it is notable that pulmonary eosinophilia is not part of the lung 269 pathology so far attributed to SARS-CoV-2. It will be important however to assess the presence 270 of eosinophils and the deposition of their granule products in the lung of a large cohort of 271 COVID-19 patients, and to control for exposure to glucocorticoids, in order to determine the role 272 of eosinophils in the COVID-19 lung pathology. Finally, and likely most importantly, there is 273 considerable concern about whether SARS-CoV-2 exposure post-vaccination would cause 274 eosinophil-associated lung pathology through immunopotentiation (see Figure 1 ). Though these 275 concerns mainly have been derived from murine studies using vaccine candidates from the 276 original SARS-CoV-1 virus, similar responses have also been seen in other species (e.g., ferrets 277 and monkey studies); it is also notable that SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2 share > 80%
The antiviral activity of eosinophils is unlikely involved in COVID-19 because the antiviral activity of eosinophils has not yet been observed in humans.
There are no data to date substantiating any risk for infections following depletion of eosinophils.
The eosinopenia associated with COVID-19 is likely a secondary phenomenon and not directly contributing to the disease course.
Vaccine candidates must demonstrate the absence of eosinophil-associated disease enhancement prior to widespread deployment. 295 296
body_text.section: Lung Eosinophilia Associated with Immunopotentiation by SARS Vaccines

body_text.text: The structural proteins of the SARS-CoV viral particle are shown and putative Th1-vs Th2-298 mediated immune responses detailed. The Spike (S) glycoprotein mediates binding of the virus 299
to the angiotensin-converting enzyme-2 (ACE2) protein and subsequent fusion/entry into host 300 cells. Sera from convalescing patients have revealed that anti-N protein and anti-S protein 301

antibodies predominate the humoral immune response to SARS-CoV-1 but that only anti-S 302 protein antibodies (especially those targeting the receptor binding domain [RBD] region) are 303 neutralizing and protective. Beneficial anti-viral responses appear to be linked to Th1-skewed 304

immunity, whereas Th2 immunopotentiation in multiple animal model systems is associated with 305 vaccination-enhanced disease, leading to pulmonary eosinophilia. To date, these potentially 306 adverse consequences have been observed only in animal model systems following virus 307 challenge with certain vaccine formulations (see Table 1 ). A variety of SARS-CoV-2 vaccine 308
candidates are currently under development (see box), which should be scrutinized for safety 309
prior to widespread deployment. ssRNA, single-stranded RNA. CTL, cytotoxic T lymphocyte. 310 311 312 313

FIGREF0.text: 70 involved in protective immunity, including antiviral responses and shaping diverse physiological 71 responses, such as organ development and metabolism. Though eosinophils are normally 72 considered blood cells, they reside in a variety of tissues. Most notably, eosinophils reside in the 73 gastrointestinal tract, which is their primary residence, and the lung, where a population of 74 regulatory eosinophils, that have unique features compared with inflammatory eosinophils, have 75 been identified. 4 76 77

FIGREF1.text: 125 extracellular traps composed of eosinophilic granule proteins bound to genomic and 126 mitochondrial DNA, and murine eosinophils can release these DNA traps in response to RSV 127 infection in vitro 21 , especially in oxidative lung tissue environments. 22 Eosinophils are also 128 capable of quickly mobilizing preformed granule pools of T H 1 cytokines, including IL-12 and 129 IFN-γ, which are important for mounting effective antiviral immune responses. 23 In a murine 130 model of allergic asthma, pulmonary eosinophils upregulate MHC-I and CD86 in response to 131 influenza virus (IFV) infection, where they can directly interact with CD8+ T cells and promote 132 recruitment of virus-specific CD8+ T cells into the lungs to enhance antiviral immunity. 24 133 Activated murine and human eosinophils also express MHC-II molecules and co-stimulatory 134 molecules and can function as antigen-presenting cells for viral antigens, leading to T cell 135 activation and cytokine secretion. 25, 26 IL-5 transgenic mice, which constitutively overproduce 136 IL-5 and have systemic eosinophilia, have accelerated viral clearance during infection with 137 RSV. 19 Conversely, mice genetically engineered to be eosinophil-deficient have lower viral 138 clearance of RSV than do wild-type controls. 19 Adoptive transfer of eosinophils from A. 139 fumigatus antigen-sensitized mice into the airways of IFV-infected mice decreases viral titers 140 and increases virus-specific CD8+ T cells in comparison to that of animals who did not receive 141 eosinophils. 24 Interestingly, human subjects with asthma were treated with the anti-eosinophil 142 drug mepolizumab (an anti-IL-5 humanized monoclonal antibody) or placebo and subsequently 143 challenged with rhinovirus; mepolizumab-treated patients demonstrated significant increases in 144 their rhinovirus viral titers in the upper airway, supporting an antiviral role for eosinophils. 27 145

FIGREF2.text: eosinophils have in different antiviral responses. Taken together, although preclinical studies 158 have demonstrated antiviral activity for eosinophils, their clinical relevance in immune responses 159 to different respiratory viruses remains unclear and needs further investigation. 160 161 3. EOSINOPHIL RESPONSE IN COVID-19 162 RV, RSV, and IFV are common triggers of viral-induced asthma exacerbations, whereas 163 coronaviruses are far less common triggers for acute asthma exacerbations. 29, 38-41 Asthma has 164 not yet been identified as a major risk factor for severity of SARS-CoV-1 infections. 42 With 165 regard to SARS-CoV-2, Zhang et al. recently reported that none of the 140 hospitalized patients 166 with confirmed COVID-19 in one hospital in Wuhan, China reported asthma or comorbid atopic 167 disease. 10 Another recent review of 548 patients admitted with COVID-19 to another hospital in 168 Wuhan reported only five cases of asthma (prevalence of 0.9%), markedly lower than the 169 prevalence of asthma within the adult population in Wuhan (6.4%). 43 Leukocytosis, with 170 increased absolute neutrophil counts, has been associated with more severe presentations of 171 COVID-19 disease. 43-46 Interestingly, Zhang et al. reported more than half of the patients 172 admitted with COVID-19 (53%) had eosinopenia (defined as absolute eosinophil counts <0.02 173 x10 9 cells/L) on the day of hospital admission. 10 Similarly, Du et al. reviewed the medical 174 records of 85 fatal cases of COVID-19 and noted that 81% of the patients had absolute 175 eosinophil counts below the normal range (absolute eosinophil counts <0.02 x10 9 cells/L) at the 176 time of admission. 47 Lymphopenia has also been a common finding in patients with COVID-177 19, 10, 43, 48, 49 and blood eosinophil counts correlated positively with lymphocytes counts in both 178 severe and non-severe cases. 10 Liu et al. also noted eosinopenia at the time of initial presentation 179 in a small cohort of patients that were treated with lopinavir. 50 Notably, eosinophil levels 180 improved in all patients prior to discharge, suggesting that resolution of eosinopenia may be an 181 indicator of improving clinical status. The pathophysiology for eosinopenia in COVID-19 182 remains unclear but is likely multifactorial, involving inhibition of eosinophil egress from the 183 bone marrow, blockade of eosinophilopoiesis, reduced expression of chemokine 184 receptors/adhesion factors 8, 51 and/or direct eosinophil apoptosis induced by type 1 interferons 185 released during the acute infection. 52 Importantly, no eosinophil enrichment into the pulmonary 186 tissue has been observed in samples from patients with COVID-19 disease at early stages of 187 disease 53 or in postmortem analyses. 54 Moreover, postmortem analysis of lung tissue from a 188 patient who died from COVID-19 demonstrated signs of acute respiratory distress syndrome that 189 was dominated by mononuclear inflammatory infiltrates, mostly lymphocytes. 55 Consequently, 190 consistent with SARS-CoV-1, asthma or other allergic comorbidities do not seem to increase risk 191 for poor outcomes with SARS-CoV-2 infections given the current evidence available. 192

FIGREF3.text: hypereosinophilic diseases have a predilection for males. 56 Taken together, although the current 198 data are limited, there is little indication that eosinophils have a protective or exacerbating role 199 during SARS-CoV-2 infection. Eosinopenia, however, may serve as a prognostic indicator for 200 more severe COVID disease. 201 202 4. VACCINE-INDUCED IMMUNOPATHOLOGY LINKED TO CORONAVIRUSES 203 Following the outbreak of the SARS epidemic in late 2002, investigators raced to develop 204 candidate SARS-CoV-1 vaccines. Diverse strategies were tested, including use of attenuated or 205 inactivated whole CoV particles, DNA-based vaccines, recombinant viral particles, and 206 recombinant subunit vaccines. 57 Sera from patients convalescing from SARS revealed robust 207 antibody titers against the spike (S) and nucleocapsid (N) protein. 58 Vaccine candidates that 208 induced neutralizing antibodies targeting the S protein demonstrated efficacy in blocking viral 209 replication, 59 a concept later confirmed by passive antibody transfer studies. 60, 61 Unfortunately, 210 anti-SARS vaccine-associated pathology emerged in early ferret (hepatitis 62 and pulmonary 211 eosinophilia 62, 63 ), cynomolgus monkey (Th2-type immunopathology with eosinophils 63, 64 ), and 212 mouse (pulmonary eosinophilia) 65 studies. SARS-CoV-1 driven, eosinophil-associated Th2 213 immunopotentiation also occurred with reinfection (green monkey model), suggesting that 214 immune enhancement of coronavirus-associated disease may be relevant in future outbreaks of 215 heterologous CoVs. 66 Eosinophil-associated disease enhancement following exposure after 216 vaccination is unfortunately not a new phenomenon. Historical reports from the 1960s link 217 administration of a candidate formalin-inactivated RSV vaccine to severe, eosinophil-associated 218 pulmonary disease following natural infection. This severe eosinophilic pulmonary disease 219 hospitalized most study participants and led to at least 2 deaths. 67-69 Memories of such disease 220 enhancement post-vaccination strongly influenced subsequent RSV F protein subunit vaccine 221 development and trial design. 70 The development of a safe and efficacious SARS-CoV-2 vaccine 222 will require the development of vaccine candidates that take into account the risk of similar 223 vaccine-associated immunopathology. 224 225

FIGREF4.text: ) 226 evaluated the factors driving the observed Th2-skewed vaccine immunopathology. Two 227 independent studies using recombinant viral particles (Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus 228 [VEEV] or Vaccinia) utilized isolated SARS structural proteins to investigate the source of 229 immunopathology. 65, 71 N-protein vaccination was implicated as a major driver of vaccine-230 associated pulmonary eosinophilia, although passive transfer of anti-N protein antibody was not 231 sufficient to drive enhanced Th2 disease, suggesting a possible role for anti-N protein-specific T 232 cells. 65 Th2-mediated disease enhancement was also linked to age, as vaccination of aged mice 233 (>12 months old) with double-inactivated SARS-CoV-1 led to increased morbidity/mortality and 234 accentuated eosinophilic pulmonary disease. 72 Follow-up studies comparing vaccination 235 strategies, vaccine preparations [whole virus/virus-like particles vs. subunits vs. subunit 236 fragments], boosting strategies and timing, and the inclusion of alum versus other adjuvants 237 (TLR agonists) have yielded variable results. In early studies, chimeric recombinant virus-like 238 particle vaccines displaying only the SARS S protein did not induce eosinophilia. 65, 71 In 239 contrast, isolated S protein subunit vaccines (Spike ΔTM [S ΔTM ]) appeared capable of Th2 240 immunopotentiation. 63, 73, 74 S protein-derived fragments containing just the receptor-binding 241 domain (RBD) have also been proposed as vaccine antigens, but these vaccine formulations have 242 required more aggressive use of adjuvants and more boosters (3-4 times more) than other 243 approaches. 57 Investigations into the Th2 immunopotentiation capacity of these compounds have 244 been limited but reassuring, with one study showing no evidence of pulmonary eosinophilia in 245 post-challenge animals 75 and a follow-up study showing balanced Th1/Th2 cytokine induction 246 following vaccination. 76 Some investigators have implicated the inclusion of the Th2-skewing 247 adjuvant alum in causing the immunopotentiation, and subsequent studies have shown that the 248 inclusion of Th1-skewing adjuvants with both whole virus and subunit vaccine candidates have 249 attenuated or blocked the development of pulmonary eosinophilia with SARS-CoV-1 250 challenge. 73, 74 Alternatively, contaminating exogenous proteins from serum-containing media 251 (i.e., bovine serum albumin) in vaccine preparation or viral stocks may explain the observed Th2 252 skewing in certain experiments; however, the absence of eosinophilic infiltrates in mock-253 vaccinated control animals makes this possibility less likely. Overall, the SARS-CoV-1 254 vaccination literature documents recurrent, post-vaccination disease enhancement in diverse 255 vaccine preparations and across multiple animal models; however, this side effect declines with 256 the use of more tightly defined antigens (S protein RBD peptide) and the use of Th1 skewing 257 adjuvants. 258 259

FIGREF5.text: 278 identify. Although the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak places new emphasis on the critical need for 279 an effective SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, safety must be a central focus for any vaccine designed for 280 general use. Current clinical reports show that the majority (up to 81%) of patients with COVID-281 19 have mild disease, 77 and therefore, trials of vaccine candidates must rigorously demonstrate 282 the absence of eosinophil-associated disease enhancement prior to widespread deployment. 283 284 285

TABREF1.text: ABBREVIATIONS: d, days; Eos, eosinophils; Infx, infection; Lymph, lymphocyte; m, months; Mac, alveolar macrophage; N, No; ND, not done; Neu, neutrophil; S ΔTM , Spike protein-transmembrane domain deleted; wks, weeks; UV, ultraviolet light; VRP, virus replicon particle; VV, vaccinia; V, virus; Y, Yes. ADJUVANT NOTES: Alum, aluminum salts; TLR agonist [LPS, poly(I:C), poly(U)]; Advax1: delta inulin microparticles; Advax2: delta inulin microparticles and CpG. Eosinophil Responses Related to COVID-19 293 294 Issue Likely Significance Atopy-related eosinophilia Atopy does not appear to have an exacerbating role in COVID-19.
